- [Runeet] Hello, my
name is Runeet Vashisht.
I'm a solutions architect at AWS,

specially focused on
Microsoft technologies
such as .NET and SQL Server on AWS.
In this session, I'm going to talk about
AWS Microservice Extractor for .NET.

AWS Microservice Extractor for
.NET simplifies the process

of refactoring your application
into independent services.

It is an assistive tool
that analyzes source code

and runtime metrics to create
a visual representation
of your application and its dependencies.

It combines data from code
analysis and runtime profiling
to create a graph that shows the metrics
and dependencies for each component.
This graph eliminates the need to manually
correlate the outputs of various tools
to perform code and runtime analysis.

AWS Microservice Extractor
for .NET identifies
potential API endpoints to be extracted
as independent services, based on coupling
between components, call counts, and more.

After you group parts of
your monolithic application

into functionalities for
extraction as separate services,

you can use AWS Microservice
Extractor for .NET

to extract independent
services that teams can work,

develop, build, deploy,
and operate independently.

Let's take a look at the
Microservice Extractor for .NET

and see how it can be used to
extract independent services

from an existing ASP.NET MVC
5-based monolithic application.

To get started with
Microservice Extractor for .NET,
you can download it at no additional cost
from aws.amazon.com.

Once downloaded, you
will see a home screen
of Microservice Extractor for .NET,
which will look something similar to this.

Before you can start working
with the application code,

you have to set the
Microservice Extractor up.

For that, click on Settings,
and then click on Edit.
The very first time,

you will see all of these
options will be empty.
Few things you have to select is,
first of all is the AWS region

with which Microservice
Extractor is gonna communicate.
The second thing is a name profile.
This is the user identity

which will be used to
make calls to AWS APIs.
If you're running it on a Dev machine,
which does not have a profile,
you will see this dropdown empty.
You can click on Add a named profile,

give profile a name, and you
have to provide AWS access

key ID and secret access
key to create the profile.
If you don't have access key,
you can go to AWS management console,

create an IAM user and
create the access key
and secret access key for that user.

In my case, I already had a
user show, a name profile,

so I'm gonna select
this from the dropdown.
The next one is the working directory.

This is the temporary
location, which will be used

via Microservice Extractor
for .NET to store the copy

of your source code, and then
work on that source code,
as you extract an independent service
from an existing monolith.

It is recommended that you
keep the path of working
directory to be short,

because when Microservice
Extractor for .NET is working
on source code in this directory,

it is going to use
MSBuild to build the code.
And there are some limitations,

if the path of your working
directory is really long,

you can see some
compilation issues as well.

The next one, as I mentioned,
Microservice Extractor

is going to build your
code at the runtime.

And for that purpose, it
is going to use MSBuild.
MSBuild is one of the prerequisites
to work with Microservice Extractor.

If you're running Microservice
Extractor on a computer
which already has Visual Studio installed,

it should have MSBuild
automatically detected

and the path will be
automatically populated for you.

The next one is the usage
data sharing option with AWS.
This is selected by default.

This helps AWS improve
Microservice Extractor for .NET,

but if you choose to opt
out, you can uncheck the box
and click on update.
With these settings in place,
you are now ready to start working
with Microservice Extractor for .NET.
Click on Update, and you'll be directed
to the homepage of the tool.
On the homepage, you'll see information

about how Microservice
Extractor works and how
it will take you through multiple stages.

In the stage one, it's gonna
help you scan your application

code and then visualize different
parts of our application.

And then it will let you
group different parts

of your application, before
you can extract those parts
as independent services.

To get started, click
on the button at the top
that says Get Started.
You will be presented with a summary
of all the steps once again.
At the top, you can see stage number one

or step number one is to
onboard your application.

Once onboarded, you can
start visualizing parts

of your application, and we
will see in just a second
how you can see different classes
of your application and interrelationship

between them depicted
by a dependency graph.

And then we will go ahead
and group those classes

and extract those classes
as independent services.

For this demo, I'm using
a sample demo application
which mimics an online web store
which looks something like this.
This is an ASP.NET MVC 5 application.
And on this homepage of the application

you can see there's a list
of products at the bottom

and then list of properties
on the left-hand side.

Let's look at the search
code of this application.
Here's the application source code.

And this application has
couple of controllers.
These are the entry point
or the front end of your application.
These controllers are calling
into different application services.

For example, there's a home
controller that we just saw,

which is showing us a list
of products and categories.

And the home controller is
making call to various services.
For example, inventory service,
to show the product information.

Similarly, there is a
order processing service

and there is a shopping
cart service as well.

Now, this application
uses entity framework,
and under the models, you will see some
data entities as well as DbContext
as well created beforehand.

Now, if my goal is to
first visualize dependency

see between different
parts of the application

and then use that dependency
to make a decision to

extract part of the application
as a separate service,

can Microservice Extractor
help me in doing that?
Let's take a look at that.
I'll go back to Microservice Extractor

and to begin extracting
an independent service,

I'm gonna start with onboarding
the application first.

For that, I'm gonna click
on Onboard application.
I'm going to give this application a name,

and in this case I'm gonna
call it GadgetsOnline.
That's the name of the sample application.

I can optionally provide
some description as well,

but for the demo, I'm
just gonna skip that step.

The next step is to provide
the path of my applications
solution file or SLN file.
And for that, I'm gonna click

on Choose file option
and navigate to the path

where my applications source
code is corporate locally.

Remember, Microservice
Extractor is going to

assess and scan your
application source code
to identify different paths
or different classes of the application

and then to identify dependency
between different classes.
So that's step number one.
Next step is, which is an optional step,
is to provide runtime profiling data,
along with the graphical user interface
which is helping me visualize part

of the application and then
break part of an application
as an independent service.

Microservice Extractor
also ships with a DLL

which can be used to profile
your existing application.
All you have to do is use that DLL,

register the DLL and update
your IES config file.
And on the runtime,

the DLL will help collect
some profiling data.
And once the data is collected,

that will help us in the
next stage of visualization

where we will see different
classes on a graph

and this data will help
us identify how many times

a particular class was getting
called from another class.

I have already collected
some data beforehand.

So let me go ahead and
point to the providing data
which I think is in providing output.

The next one, again, this
is an optional setting.

It is integration with
Porting Assistant for .NET.
Porting Assistant for .NET

is another assistive tool
which can help you analyze,

assess and estimate your
.NET framework applications
and see how much

of that application is
compatible with .NET Core.

Porting Assistant gives
out list of NuGet packages

which are not compatible,
as well as API calls
which are not compatible with .NET Core.

Along with that, you
also get recommendations

and suggestions about NuGet
packages and about API calls

which will be compatible
with .NET Core or .NET 5.

Now, Microservice Extractor
can do that assessment

for you, along with doing
the rest of the operations

if you have Porting
Assistant or .NET running
on the same machine.

In my case, I do have
Porting Assistant running,
so I do want to asses my application
using Porting Assistant for .NET as well.
Well, with these settings in place,

I'm now ready to start working
with Microservice Extractor.
So I'm gonna click on onboard application.

Now, you can see at the
top that my onboarding

is currently going on and
I can see the same thing
in the onboarding status as well.

And right now, Microservice
Extractor is creating a copy

of my source code, dropping
it into the working directory
compiling the code, and trying to identify

all different classes in
that application code,
and relationship between those classes.

It will also use Porting
Assistant to assess the code
and find out compatibility with .NET Core.
This can take couple of minutes,
so I'm gonna pause the video

and come back once
onboarding is completed.

All right, the onboarding
process is completed now

and the status has changed
from in progress to success.

And now I'm ready to go to
next step or next stage,

which is to visualize
parts of my application.

To do that, I'm gonna
select the application

from this list and click
on launch visualization.
Now, what you see on the screen here
is the visual representation
of different classes in my application.
And if I zoom in,

I can see the name of
those classes as well.
So in this dependency graph,

each node depicts a particular
class in my application code,

and each edge between these
nodes depicts the relationship
or dependency between the classes.

For example, I just
selected the inventory node,

or inventory class, and I can
see that this inventory class

has three outgoing orange
arrows, and orange arrows,

in this case, denotes the
outgoing or outbound dependency.
So, this inventory class depends
on my migration configuration,

and it depends on category
class in my Models namespace.
Similarly, a couple of other classes.

Similarly, these blue arrows
denote an incoming dependency
in my inventory class.

You can see my inventory
class currently is used
by my home controller, store controller,
as well as shopping cart controller.
Another important thing to notice here is

since we had the usage
metrics, if I look at any

of the edges between the
classes, I also get a call count.
For example, my inventory class called
the category class around 400 times
during the data collection time.
Similarly, inventory class got called
from home controller once.
And from my shopping cart controller

around four times while
this data was collected.
Now, there are a couple
of other visualization options as well.

You can click on Explore
alternate visualizations

for grouping at the top,
and that will show you
your classes organized little differently.

I can cancel it from
no details and zoom in
and now I can see

that my classes are now
organized as for the namespaces.

All the services classes are
in the services namespace.

All the controllers are in
the controller namespace.

Of course, I'm gonna
get similar information
if I select the same inventory class,
which is part of my services namespace.

Now I can always switch
back to the original view
by clicking on Back to main view.
By using this information,

I can now start thinking
about how am I going to

create independent services
from my existing application.

For example, if my goal is to
create an independent service
using just the inventory class,

which has dependency on couple
of entity framework entities,
and there are a couple of controllers
which depend on inventory class,
all I have to do is select the class,

right click on it, and
add this class to a group.
Remember, group is the unit of extraction.

I'm eventually going to
group one or more classes

and then extract that group
as independent service.
Now, to add a class to the group,

I can right click and
click on Add node to group.

Since this is the first
time I'm creating a group,
I don't have any existing groups,
so I'm gonna click on Create new,

and going to give it an
name, InventoryService.
I can have more than one groups,

and to visually differentiate
between the groups,
I can give any group color as well.

Now, as soon as I select a
group color, all the nodes

in that group will be
changed to that color.
Like in this case, it's the green color.

A few things to notice,
on the right-hand side,

I'm getting .NET Core
portability information,
and since this group has only one node,

I'm getting an information
that my inventory
class is compatible with .NET Core,
which is a good sign because it tells me
that once my new project will be created

or once inventory is created
as an independent service,

I can potentially port it to
.NET Core and then take benefit

of maybe containerize it
using Linux Containers.

Another thing is I also
get a similar information

in terms of dependency
under the Node summary,

so you see the same orange
and yellow arrows, which talks
about dependency between the classes.
In the general tab, I see some information

about what is a class
inside of this group,

and what are the other classes
that this group depends on.
Now, with this information,
now I'm ready to extract the group.

And one more thing before
we start extracting,

you can always add more
classes to the group.
In your real application,

most likely you're gonna
have more than one classes.
You can drag and drop nodes

if you want to add a node
to another group, like this,
or you can always drag it out

or drag it outside of the group
to remove it from the group.

But once you're ready,
you can select the group

and click on Extract group,
which will take you to the next

screen, where we will
start extracting this class
as an independent service.

In the next step, I am
prompted for some information
about the service that is to be extracted.

The first one is what do I
want to name this service?

So in my case, I'm just gonna
call it InventoryService.
I can optionally give description as well.

It's gonna take few
seconds to perhaps a minute
or so to make sure that the relationship
between the nodes that are being extracted

and the dependency between
the node and the rest

of the application is
identified one last time
before the extraction happens.

I'm gonna pause the video while
the metadata for extraction

is getting prepared up, and
once this metadata is ready

we should be good to actually
extract a microservice
containing the InventoryService.
Okay, so the meta data collection is done
and now I can see the list of the nodes
which are to be extracted,
which in this case is my inventory class.
And it has dependency on 20 other objects,

which includes both the custom
classes, which were part

of the solution, as
well as system objects,

such as System.Data.Entity.DbSet,
and a lot more.

With this list ready,
now I'm ready to extract.

One last thing is it is still
possible for me to extract

a microservice and still keep
my invocations to be local

in the existing monolithic
service, or I can modify a copy

of a monolithic service and
change the end locations
to remote invocations.

And in that case, all the
calls to inventory service,

all the local calls to inventory
services will be converted
into a remote request API calls.

With that setting in place,
I'm ready to click on extract.

Now the extraction process
is going to take some time.
You can see the status at the top.
So it is going to do the analysis,

do the compilation of the

different ASP.NET

via the API project, and then
a copy of existing monolith
application will be modified.

And the local calls to inventory
class will be converted

into a remote request API
calls to the inventory service.

and once it's done, I'm

I can copy this path and

And in the InventoryService,

I can double click open

The same thing as if I go back

I can find there is copy

to start calling the

which is also available
in the same folder.
Let me open both the solutions

So, post-successful

that in the working directory,
there are two folders created.
One is for the extracted service.
This is where the independent service
or the microservice is created.
And the other one is the modified copy
of my existing application.

Let's take a look at
the extracted services
source code first.
So here is the extracted service

and you would notice
Inventory.cs is the class,

which I intended to
extract as a microservice.
So the whole class is copied as it is,
all the dependencies,
which is my entity framework data model,
as well as DbContext,
all those classes were also copied
in the microservice code.

In the controller, the
functionality of Inventory.cs class
is exposed as as an API controller.
So that's why a new controller
is created call as an API controller.

One thing worth noting here is
when a service is extracted,

it's not 100% possible
that your service is
in the compilable state.

It is possible that you might
run into compilation issues.
For example, when I did this extraction,

the Microservice Extractor
decided to bring along

Db migrations, which may
or may not be required.

And there were some files which
were attempted to be brought
over, but those files did not exist,

and hence, I'm going to run
into missing file exception
if I try to compile this application.

So you might have to do the
refactoring post-extraction just

to make sure that your
microservice can be extracted.
Now, let's look at the application code,
which has been modified.

application code, how my
inventory service was called,
and then we'll look at the modified code.
So here is my original MVC 5 application.
I'm in HomeController.cs.
And in home controller,

I'm creating an instance
of inventory class.

And in the index section,
I am creating a method
called GetBestSellers on the instance
of my inventory class object.

After extraction, this code
needs to be modified because

in the modified application,
rather than calling a local

inventory class, I want
to call remote APIs
through XTP?? standpoint.

Let's take a look at the
modified application code,

the changes which AWS Microservices
Extractor for .NET made.

Here is the modified version
of the code, the changes

which AWS Microservice
Extractor for .NET made
in my existing application.
So first thing you will see is rather

than calling into the
local inventory class

it is calling a method
called GetEndpointAdapter
on the InventoryEndpointFactory.

It's also worth noticing that
while making these changes,

there was an EndpointAdapter
that was added
to my existing ASP.NET application.

And this EndpointAdapter has
the endpoint adapt factory
which can either return a remote endpoint
or a local endpoint.

It's worth noticing that the
local class is still retained.

So I still have my local
Inventory.services.
And if I want to use local calls

in place of remote API
calls, all I have to do is,
in my endpoint adapter, which was created

by Microservice Extractor,
there is Web.config.
I can modify that Web.config,
and modifying the setting remote routing
to microservices from true to false.
And with that setting, all the calls
from the endpoint factory will be routed
to the local copy of InventiveService.
That's one thing.

Another thing is Microservice
Extractor is going to
use best efforts to make these changes,
but these are not foolproof.

Depending upon how you were
originally instantiating

an object of inventory class,
your code may look different

and it's possible that
the Microservice Extractor

may not be able to
modify your code as well.

And in those cases, you
might need to do refactoring

of your code to make
sure that in your code
you are leveraging the endpoint factory
to make remote SVA call.

So that will be the refactoring
part that developers

may still have to do
post-extraction phase.

With that, we have come to
the end of this demonstration.
What we saw was a step-by-step walkthrough

of using AWS Microservice
Extractor for .NET.

We started with onboarding
the application where

we pointed the Microservice
Extractor for .NET
to sample ASP.NET MVC 5 application.

This application was analyzed
and source group was scanned.

And then in the next phase,
a visual representation

of application was created
where we could see the nodes
and the relationship between those nodes
where the nodes were different classes
and the relationship was the dependency
between those classes.
And then in the next stage,

we selected one node,
which in this example
was an inventory class, created a group

with a single node called
as InventoryService,

and extracted that group
as a separate microservice.

And in the end, what we
got was microservice,
a separate ASP.NET web API project

exposing my inventory
class over the arrest API
using an API controller.

And my existing application
code was modified
using an endpoint adapter,
and wherever I was making the local calls

to my inventory service,
those calls were replaced

by the remote API calls
using the endpoint factory.
Thanks for watching this video.

I hope you found the
step-by-step tutorial useful.
To get started,

you can go to
aws.amazon.com/microservice-extractor.

Download the Microservice
Extractor for .NET tool,

and try it with your
application source code.
Thank you.
